Travis endpoints: ‘.org’ vs ‘.com’

Source: vignettes/org-vs-com.Rmd
org-vs-com.Rmd

Overview

When dealing with Travis CI (or the {travis} package) the first time, one might be confused what the difference is between https://travis-ci.org and https://travis-ci.com. This devops.stackexchange question gives some insights on the history of both services and why both still exist.

TL;DR

  • Both https://travis-ci.org and https://travis-ci.com are the same whereas the future belongs to https://travis-ci.com
  • Due to both being still active, the {travis} package supports both endpoints for API queries.
  • If you start a new project, we recommend to enable the repo on https://travis-ci.com. If you are using the {travis] package, you can set the environment variable R_TRAVIS to ".com" to always use this endpoint when calling a function from this package.

Github Apps

For both endpoints different “Github Apps” exist. These apps are needed if you want to have the interactive status checks during Pull Requests. For .com, you can activate the app via https://github.com/apps/travis-ci/installations. The app for the old .org endpoint cannot be actively installed anymore. It differs in the way that it is named “Travis CI for open-source” whereas the .com app is named “Travis CI” only.
